summary: Email chain between defense attorney Bruce Barket and Assistant U.S. Attorneys regarding requests for statements made by inmate Nicholas Tartaglione concerning Jeffrey Epstein's reported suicide attempt in July 2019. The prosecution provides some statements but denies requests for video and reports of the incident itself, citing relevance and procedural grounds.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione

connections.description: Bruce Barket is the defense attorney requesting statements and evidence on behalf of his client, Nicholas Tartaglione.
Defense attorney corresponding with Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding evidence production and legal requests.
Tartaglione was interviewed by MCC/BOP staff regarding an event involving Jeffrey Epstein's reported suicide attempt, suggesting he may have witnessed or had information about the incident.
Both are Assistant U.S. Attorneys working together on the case, coordinating responses to defense requests.

events.title: Reported Epstein Suicide Attempt at MCC
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's reported attempted suicide at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, which prompted interviews with inmate Nicholas Tartaglione.

events.title: Email Correspondence on Evidence Requests
events.description: Series of emails between defense attorney Bruce Barket and Assistant U.S. Attorneys regarding requests for Tartaglione's statements and video of Epstein's incident.

locations: 666 Old Country Road, Ste. 700, Garden City, NY 11530
keyFacts: The defense attorney for Nicholas Tartaglione requested statements Tartaglione made to MCC/BOP staff regarding Jeffrey Epstein's reported suicide attempt on July 22-23, 2019.
The U.S. Attorney's Office produced a zip folder with reports of Tartaglione's statements, including statements attributed to Tartaglione that were conveyed to MCC staff by Epstein.
The prosecution denied the defense's request for all reports and video of Epstein's attempted suicide, stating they are not relevant to the case or covered under Rule 16.
The correspondence references a prior letter from the defense to the MCC asking for preservation of video evidence shortly after the Epstein incident.
